abstracts.cdata!:
The audit accords with the
            Implementation Completion Report ratings of unsatisfactory
            project outcome, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts. The overall disappointing
            performance mainly reflects over-ambitious objectives for
            such a short implementation period, and a government change
            at the outset, which exposed incomplete commitment to the
            project strategy, exacerbating design, and preparation
            shortfalls. The experience of this project confirms a number
            of lessons: 1) in responding to emergencies, assistance in a
            conventional project format should be limited to the
            immediate emergency, while a series of Adjustable Program
            Loans, may be a better instrument for longer term needs; 2)
            a thorough political risk analysis, and ensured broad
            political support - e.g., privatization, and utility tariff
            modification - is essential whenever government, or policy
            changes could occur; 3) contract management should consider,
            and avoid potential conflicts of interest, by excluding
            contractors who bid on the preparation of privatization
            arrangements from bidding on supply, and construction
            contracts, or the privatization itself; and, carefully
            foster incentives and/or penalties in management contracts,
            to ensure proper contractor performance; and, 4) greater
            consistency is needed in project documents, so as to improve
            understanding, and agreement in the statement of objectives,
            and project description.
